i am writing to express support for proposed changes outlined in document cms-1701-p as they relate to beneficiary engagement. specifically, i want to encourage the continued inclusion of the proposal to incentivize beneficiaries to achieve and maintain good health. health behavior change theory generally predicts that up to 20% of at-risk individuals are prepared to initiate beneficial behavior change at any given time (1). health behavior change is difficult, often overwhelming, and typically an up-and-down journey over the course of a lifetime. that being said, the majority of us healthcare dollars are spent on treating chronic conditions and diseases like diabetes, arthritis, and heart disease, which make up 7 of the 10 leading causes of death in our country (2). morbidity, mortality, and costs related to chronic disease are too high compared to peer countries, especially given that many of these conditions are preventable (3). behaviors related to diet and physical activity drive the majority of this crisis (4)(5). thus enabling behavior change on a large-scale is a necessity that we cannot afford to overlook.

accountable care organizations like those in the mssp are in a unique position to create opportunities for beneficiaries to become aware of and be actively connected to evidence-based behavior change programming. by placing increased accountability on providers and their respective systems to keep beneficiaries healthy before disease or crisis occurs, acos can help move the intervention point of patient care upstream. at-risk individuals are more likely to pursue behavior change when encouraged by their clinician (6)(7), but as many health educators and community-based providers of behavior change programming can attest, the most difficult barrier can be getting a person to commit to the behavior change process after leaving the healthcare providers office. incentivizing behavior change as a series of steps to achieve and maintain good health would help motivate the individual to take action on a challenging process, and give the provider working within the aco a stronger platform on which to advocate that the patient take advantage of behavior change program opportunities outside of the clinical environment, at places implementing evidence-based approaches like the ymca.

one major example is the national diabetes prevention program (dpp). more than one in three us adults (and nearly one in two adults age 65+) have prediabetes and would be eligible for participation in the dpp (8). community-based organizations like the ymca have gone to great lengths to meet the requirements of becoming certified medicare suppliers of the dpp to try and make non-clinical health services accessible to people in the places they live and spend time. while the clinical need for the program is statistically guaranteed to be present in every community, ymcas nationwide face difficulty in getting the volume of dpp participants necessary to fill classes. awareness of personal risk and of opportunities to mitigate risk, and reaching a sufficient readiness-to-change level, are two of the main challenges. giving acos the option to incentivize behavior change such as enrollment in behavior-change programming like dpp would support an infrastructure in which providers are systematically encouraged to partner with community-based services and connect patients to supportive programming outside the clinic, as well as provide another layer of motivation (through incentives) for an at-risk individual to choose to initiate the behavior change process.

(1) prochaska j, velic wf. the transtheoretical model of health behavior change. american journal of health promotion. 1997;12(1):38-48
(2) cdc 2018: https://www.cdc.gov/chronicdisease/about/costs/index.htm
(3) oecd health at a glance, 2015: https://www.oecd.org/unitedstates/health-at-a-glance-2015-key-findings-united-states.pdf
(4) cdc 2017: https://www.cdc.gov/chronicdisease/resources/publications/aag/dnpao.htm
(5) millen b, lichtenstein ah, abrams s. u.s. department of health and human services and the u.s. department of agriculture. dietary guidelines for americans 2015-2020: https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/2015/guidelines/introduction/nutrition-and-health-are-closely-related/
(6) pool ac, kraschnewski jl, cover la, et al. the impact of physician weight discussion on weight loss in us adults. obesity research & clinical practice. 2014;8(2):e131-e139. doi:10.1016/j.orcp.2013.03.003
(7) rose sa, poynter ps, anderson jw, et al. physician weight loss advice and patient weight loss behavior change: a literature review and meta-analysis of survey data. international journal of obesity. 2012;37(118). doi:10.1038/ijo.2012.24
(8) cdc 2018: https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/data/statistics-report/prevalence.html

dear administrator verma,

i am writing to voice both opposition to and support of the pathways to success proposed rule.

as a way of background, i represent a physician-led aco, finishing up its first agreement period as a track 1 mssp. during the first three years, we have learned much. one of the things we know is that limiting the number of years in a non-risk bearing aco will be detrimental to existing acos and will discourage potential new entrants from joining the program.

as a small, rural-based, physician-led aco, these three years have been an enormous learning process. due to delayed data, it is very difficult for an aco to make targeted change until nearly half-way through its first year. extending the length of time an aco is eligible to be non-risk bearing does not mean the aco is not working to make changes. our aco, for example, has implemented initiatives to reduce expenditures and our physicians are actively engaged. however, we continue to see in our quarterly reports rising part a expenditures. while we have a physician-owned specialty hospital in our aco, we do not have a community-based hospital and therefore have very little ability to affect costs in the hospital. in addition, because of our rural setting, we also struggle with the cost of critical access hospitals as these hospitals are used on a regular basis and contribute greatly to our expenses.

the other area of increasing expenditure is part b drugs. we believe a large contributing factor to this growth is the health systems participation in the 340b program. since our aco began, this line item has increased 82%. again, we have no way to control this cost.

these examples are given as a way to show our support for the consideration of low revenue vs. high revenue acos. we believe that small acos in rural areas face challenges that large health systems do not. data shows that physician-led acos are more successful in saving money. we believe we are implementing change that will have an impact, but struggle to show the impact due to costs that are largely out of our control.

we also support the reduction in quality reporting measures, as it reduces administrative burden.

because of the time it takes to get the aco operational, we also support the cms proposal to extend the agreement periods to five years; however, we oppose the move from six years in the non-risk track to two years. we also oppose the agencys proposal to cut the shared savings rate from 50% to 25%.

as our participants are new to the risk adjustment concept, we also urge cms to modify the proposed application of a +/- 3 percent risk adjustment cap across an extended period by increasing that rate to +/- 5 percent.

because of the significant changes proposed to the program, and the lateness of the proposal, we also suggest that the start-date for implementation of pathways to success be moved from july 1, 2019 to january 1, 2020.

thank you again for your work on behalf of patients and providers to advance value-based payment. we appreciate your interest in sustaining the success of medicare acos and creating an environment where providers are encouraged to enter into value-based payment arrangements and help patients receive high-quality, coordinated care.

sincerely,

ceo
dakota healthcare partners dba accocare

sioux falls, sd 57105

re: comments on pathways to success mssp proposed rule
dear administrator verma,
augusta care partners is an accountable care organization (aco) based in rural virginia that represents a strong partnership between independent physician practices and a community hospital with employed providers. we are currently in our second agreement period as a track 1 aco in the medicare shared savings program (mssp).
it is important to note that while our aco has not yet achieved shared savings, we have maintained quality scores in the top quartile of all mssp acos and, at the same time, have sustained one of the lowest cost-per-beneficiary rates across all mssp acos. these results can be directly tied to significant investments in improving coordination of care and our team of providers being committed to generating positive outcomes for medicare beneficiaries in our community. as a administrative leader for augusta care partners, i feel it is important to voice my opinion on a few key points in the mssp proposed rule, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizations pathways to success.
providing an opportunity to choose prospective attribution in both the basic and enhanced tracks is a significant improvement. our aco has been challenged by the uncertainty of preliminary prospective beneficiary assignment with retrospective reconciliation. having the option to definitively know our attributed patient panel at the beginning of the year offers some much-needed stability and helps guide the appropriate allocation of our acos finite resources.
the flexibility offered by the snf waiver is a huge benefit. i appreciate that cms is expanding access to this important program feature.
i am hopeful that the 5 year agreement periods offered in both the basic and enhanced tracks will create increased predictability in the program. it is also a welcome change to have risk scores updated annually for the acos total population, instead of differentiating between newly assigned and continuously assigned beneficiaries. i am concerned, however, that limiting the risk adjustment to +/- 3% over that 5 year agreement period will not protect providers who serve our most medically complicated patients. medicare beneficiaries can experience significant changes in health status over 5 years, and those changes may not be adequately addressed by the proposed methodology. our aco has been challenged by a benchmark that does not adequately reflect the health of our population. we have worked hard to understand the mssps complex benchmarking rules and to raise awareness about the importance of coding specificity to care coordination. i am concerned that, despite our demonstrated track record of low cost and high quality, the +/- 3% cap will disadvantage our aco by continuing to incorrectly capture the health status of our beneficiaries, making shared savings unattainable.
its no secret that the abstraction of quality metrics is an onerous process, and i am encouraged by the current administrations efforts to reduce reporting burden for providers. i am also a strong advocate for transparency in scoring. should cms choose to increase the number of claims-based measures, it would be extremely helpful to provide user-friendly, actionable reports that detail the aco-specific data used to calculate specific measure performance.
i am concerned about how the enhanced notification requirements will impact my office workflow and efficiency. it will be challenging to add one more piece of paper to the stack of important documents my patients are asked to review and acknowledge at each visit. also, while i appreciate the option of providing beneficiary incentives, the administrative burden of implementation and tracking would likely create additional frustration for staff and add expense to my offices operations.
thank you for taking my comments into consideration as you work to streamline the mssp model. i look forward to seeing continued improvements in the coming years that will benefit the patients we serve and allow me and our aco participants to focus on providing high-quality and efficient care to our community.
sincerely,
daniel o'connor
executive director
augusta care partners

i respectfully request cms change their input to reflect that rural acos should not be required to take risk.

my concerns about mssp proposed rule for 2019 to cms include:
1.our rural aco is a high-quality performer and is saving cms money.
2.the rocky mtn aco is based in rural practices and rural facilities that lack capital reserves and cannot take on risk.
3.the proposed 25% shared savings opportunity is not worth the effort.
4.we should be considered "low revenue". our aco is rural and therefore should be considered low revenue.

new study released this week confirms mssp acos are generating significant savings for cms.
the medicare shared savings program (mssp) acos are improving quality and saving medicare significantly more than cms originally calculated. the national association of accountable care organizations (naacos) commissioned dobson davanzo & associates to conduct an independent evaluation of mssp aco cost savings. they found that acos in the mssp generated savings of $1.84b from 2013-2015, nearly double the $954m in savings estimated by cms. after accounting for shared savings bonuses, acos actually saved medicare $541.7m. discussed in todays health affairs blog, the study used a gold standard regression analysis to evaluate the program versus the cms benchmarking methodology used for financial targets and calculating bonuses or penalties.

2017 mssp aco results
newly released 2017 mssp results further demonstrated continued savings for cms. using the benchmarking methodology, cms saved $1.1b in 2017 alone, netting just shy of $314m after accounting for shared savings payments earned by acos.

re: comments on pathways to success mssp proposed rule

dear administrator verma,

augusta care partners is an accountable care organization (aco) based in rural virginia that represents a strong partnership between independent physician practices and a community hospital with employed providers. we are currently in our second agreement period as a track 1 aco in the medicare shared savings program (mssp).

it is important to note that while our aco has not yet achieved shared savings, we have maintained quality scores in the top quartile of all mssp acos and, at the same time, have sustained one of the lowest cost-per-beneficiary rates across all mssp acos. these results can be directly tied to significant investments in improving coordination of care and our team of providers being committed to generating positive outcomes for medicare beneficiaries in our community. as an administrative leader supporting our augusta care partners providers, i feel it is important to voice my opinion on a few key points in the mssp proposed rule, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizations pathways to success.

providing an opportunity to choose prospective attribution in both the basic and enhanced tracks is a significant improvement. our aco has been challenged by the uncertainty of preliminary prospective beneficiary assignment with retrospective reconciliation. having the option to definitively know our attributed patient panel at the beginning of the year offers some much-needed stability and helps guide the appropriate allocation of our acos finite resources.

the flexibility offered by the snf waiver is a huge benefit. i appreciate that cms is expanding access to this important program feature.

i am hopeful that the 5 year agreement periods offered in both the basic and enhanced tracks will create increased predictability in the program. it is also a welcome change to have risk scores updated annually for the acos total population, instead of differentiating between newly assigned and continuously assigned beneficiaries. i am concerned, however, that limiting the risk adjustment to +/- 3% over that 5 year agreement period will not protect providers who serve our most medically complicated patients. medicare beneficiaries can experience significant changes in health status over 5 years, and those changes may not be adequately addressed by the proposed methodology. our aco has been challenged by a benchmark that does not reflect the health of our population. we have worked hard to understand the mssps complex benchmarking rules and to raise awareness about the importance of coding specificity to care coordination. i am concerned that, despite our demonstrated track record of low cost and high quality, the +/- 3% cap will disadvantage our aco by continuing to incorrectly capture the health status of our beneficiaries, making shared savings unattainable.

its no secret that the abstraction of quality metrics is an onerous process, and i am encouraged by the current administrations efforts to reduce reporting burden for providers. i am also a strong advocate for transparency in scoring. should cms choose to increase the number of claims-based measures, it would be extremely helpful to provide user-friendly, actionable reports that detail the aco-specific data used to calculate specific measure performance.

i am concerned about how the enhanced notification requirements will impact office workflow and efficiency for our providers. it will be challenging to add one more piece of paper to the stack of important documents our patients are asked to review and acknowledge at each visit. also, while i appreciate the option of providing beneficiary incentives, the administrative burden of implementation and tracking would likely create additional frustration for staff and add expense to office operations.

thank you for taking my comments into consideration as you work to streamline the mssp model. i look forward to seeing continued improvements in the coming years that will benefit the patients served by our aco and allow our aco participants to focus on providing high-quality and efficient care to our community.

sincerely,
mary arrowood
operations manager
augusta care partners

as you know, under the current medicare shared savings program (mssp) beneficiary assignment regulations, an np is an authorized aco professional, but their patients cannot be assigned to the aco unless they receive one primary care service from a primary care physician participating with the aco each year. this has inhibited np practices from joining or establishing shared savings aco's and limited the scope of the shared savings program (mssp). if the mssp is to continue to develop and improve patient access, quality and cost effectiveness, it must be fully inclusive of nps and their patients.

therefore, i support cms' proposal to update the voluntary alignment option for beneficiary assignment in the shared savings program (mssp). this proposal would allow a patient to choose an np as their primary shared savings aco clinician and be assigned to an mssp aco without requiring a primary care service from a primary care physician. this proposal will increase the participation of nps and their patients in the mssp and is consistent with a patient-centered approach to health care delivery.

re: cms-1701-p, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizationspathways to success

dear administrator verma,

on behalf of our communitys accountable care organization, community health provider alliance (chpa), we would like to take this opportunity to express the interest federally qualified health centers (referred to here as fqhcs, or health centers) have in the medicare shared savings program (mssp).

our aco is a non-profit community-based organization comprised solely of fqhcs in colorado. our health centers are non-profit, community-directed providers that serve as the primary medical home for 790,000 patients in our state, including more than 1 in 7 coloradoans.

we welcome the opportunity to respond to cms pathways to success nprm. while we believe the proposed rule includes important steps toward increased success, there are several areas where we raise caution and seek clarification. in summary, our comments will focus on the following areas:
health centers are important partners in accountable care arrangements, producing cost savings for the system and enhanced quality of care for beneficiaries and look forward to continuing this work together.
cms should invest in a more gradual pathway to increased levels of financial risk for low-revenue provider-led accountable care organizations (acos), with consideration made to those acos comprised solely of fqhcs.
many fqhcs, because they provide care to some of the most underserved communities in the country, require additional investment to prepare for two-sided risk arrangements.
increased flexibility in the ability to provide telehealth services will support health centers participating in the pathways to success program.
a more appropriate benchmarking process will support participating health centers in delivering the best care for the vulnerable populations they serve.
cms should be mindful of inadvertently causing cherry-picking of patients by allowing acos to provide beneficiary incentives.

we are in opposition to a few key aspects of the recent proposed pathways to success rule, in particular the agency's proposal to cut acos shared savings rates below 50 percent, reduce the time in a shared savings-only model from six to two years, and application of a +/- 3 percent risk adjustment cap across an extended agreement period.

our opposition to and rationale for these proposed changes are outlined in the attached document.

these proposed changes will harm patients and providers by limiting improvements in savings and quality acos provide, while slowing progress made in transitioning to value-base payments. our aco has made a significant investment in funding the operations to support the mssp, and a reduction in potential savings will greatly impact our ability to reinvest in our care models/teams and will significantly limit our ability to generate enough capital to meet the repayment mechanism requirements. as a non-profit, low revenue aco, our aco may be forced out of the mssp because we will lack the capital required for the repayment mechanism. our initial intention was to build up that capital over the course of 6 years under the current system, but that timeline is drastically reduced with the proposed changes.

on the other hand, we support a number of proposals in the rule and encourage cms to finalize its proposals to: 1) move to five-year agreement periods; 2) reduce burdens related to quality reporting; 3) expand the use of waivers for telehealth and skilled nursing facility stays; and 4) provide flexibility with choosing assignment methodology regardless of risk model.

thank you again for your work on behalf of patients and providers to advance value-based payment. we appreciate your interest in sustaining the success of medicare acos and creating an environment where providers are encouraged to enter into value-based payment arrangements and help patients receive high-quality, coordinate care.


sincerely,

re: cms-1701-p, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizationsâpathways to success
dear administrator verma,
on behalf of our communityâs accountable care organization, community health provider alliance (chpa), we would like to take this opportunity to express the interest federally qualified health centers (referred to here as fqhcs, or âhealth centersâ) have in the medicare shared savings program (mssp).
our aco is a not-for-profit community-based organization comprised solely of fqhcs in colorado.  our health centers are non-profit, community-directed providers that serve as the primary medical home for 790,000 patients in our state, including more than 1 in 7 coloradoans.
we welcome the opportunity to respond to cmsâ pathways to success nprm.  while we believe the proposed rule includes important steps toward increased success, there are several areas where we raise caution and seek clarification.  in summary, our comments will focus on the following areas:
health centers are important partners in accountable care arrangements, producing cost savings for the system and enhanced quality of care for beneficiaries and look forward to continuing this work together.
cms should invest in a more gradual pathway to increased levels of financial risk for low-revenue provider-led accountable care organizations (acos), with consideration made to those acos comprised solely of fqhcs.
many fqhcs, because they provide care to some of the most underserved communities in the country, require additional investment to prepare for two-sided risk arrangements.
increased flexibility in the ability to provide telehealth services will support health centers participating in the pathways to success program.
a more appropriate benchmarking process will support participating health centers in delivering the best care for the vulnerable populations they serve.
cms should be mindful of inadvertently causing âcherry-pickingâ of patients by allowing acos to provide beneficiary incentives.
we are in opposition to a few key aspects of the recent proposed pathways to success rule, in particular the agency's proposal to cut acos shared savings rates below 50 percent, reduce the time in a shared savings-only model from six to two years, and application of a +/- 3 percent risk adjustment cap across an extended agreement period.
these proposed changes will harm patients and providers by limiting improvements in savings and quality acos provide, while slowing progress made in transitioning to value-base payments. our aco has made a significant investment in funding the operations to support the mssp, and a reduction in potential savings will greatly impact our ability to reinvest in our care models/teams and will significantly limit our ability to generate enough capital to meet the repayment mechanism requirements.  as a non-profit, low revenue aco, our aco may be forced out of the mssp because we will lack the capital required for the repayment mechanism. our initial intention was to build up that capital over the course of 6 years under the current system, but that timeline is drastically reduced with the proposed changes.
we appreciate cmsâ recognition of the additional time many provider-led acos may need to transition to higher levels of two-sided risk by allowing provider-led acos to cycle through the âbasicâ track for two agreement periods.  however, this still only allows provider-led acos two years without taking on financial risk. due to the pace of data sharing and the imperative to transform care models, we recommend cms allow provider-led acos an even more gradual pathway to two-sided risk. specifically, we suggest cms allow provider-led acos a minimum of three years in the âbasicâ track in an upside-only arrangement.
while we support incorporating regional expenditures in the benchmark established for an acoâs first agreement, we are concerned that the two proposed policies to limit the magnitude of the adjustment undermines the policy goals. as cms has recognized, the incorporation of regional expenditures provides an aco with a benchmark that is more reflective of ffs spending in the acoâs region than a benchmark based solely on the acoâs own historical expenditures. this approach creates stronger financial incentives for acos that have been successful in reducing expenditures to remain in the program, thus improving program sustainability. it also allows cms to better capture the cost experience in the acoâs region, the health status and socio-economic dynamics of the regional population, and location-specific medicare payments when compared to using national ffs expenditures.
we disagree that higher weights for the regional adjustment results in potential windfall gains to lower-cost acos. those gains are not windfalls but compensate lower-cost acos for the work invested in practices to reduce the overall costs of care for medicare beneficiaries. in fact, a lower-cost aco composed of fqhcs may have higher expenditures for primary care due to the prospective payment system (pps) methodology as compared to regional expenditures for primary care services that are generally reimbursed under the medicare fee schedule.  the risk adjustment benchmarking cap uniquely will harm our non-profit fqhc-based aco. in the past, our coding processes were fairly rudimentary which is evidenced by our unusually low risk adjustment scores and unusually low benchmarks given the patient population we serve.  our networkâs understanding of risk adjustment is relatively new, but weâve implemented coding improvement efforts to more accurately reflect the acuity of our patients and to better capture hcc codes annually.  the proposed limit of +/-3% would mitigate our efforts to improve in these crucial areas which impact our ability to be successful in the mssp.
on the other hand, we support a number of proposals in the rule and encourage cms to finalize its proposals to: 1) move to five-year agreement periods; 2) reduce burdens related to quality reporting; 3) expand the use of waivers for telehealth and skilled nursing facility stays; and 4) provide flexibility with choosing assignment methodology regardless of risk model.
the proposed provisions related to allowing acos to provide and be reimbursed for telehealth services, will help health centers continue to meet the unique needs of their communities in the most cost-efficient ways. however, while the preamble to the proposed rule outlines the process for which a provider can be reimbursed for his or her telehealth work, it is not clear how this new provision will impact health centers.  health centers are currently limited to serving as originating sites only and are not able to provide or be reimbursed as a distant site in medicare.  the preamble and proposed rule make reference to âphysicians and providersâ using the acoâs tin, however it is not clear if this provision will allow health centers to fully participate in the telehealth provisions.   we encourage cms to clarify the language in the proposed rule in order to clearly allow health centers to provide this valuable service through their work in an aco.
fqhcs are unique in that they are both required by federal law and committed to serving everyone that seeks care and must serve communities most in need of care. they turn no patient away, regardless of income, insurance status, risk, or complexity. this open-door policy is a defining feature of the health center mission of providing quality, affordable access to care to all who need it. additionally, beneficiariesâ freedom of choice is an important way for practices and payers, including medicare, to gauge practice effectiveness and the demand for access to health care services in specific communities. should cms decide to allow acos to incentivize beneficiaries, it should implement safeguards to ensure that higher-revenue acos do not inadvertently attract healthier patients, potentially skewing quality metrics and leaving sicker patients with fewer options.
thank you again for your work on behalf of patients and providers to advance value-based payment. we appreciate your interest in sustaining the success of medicare acos and creating an environment where providers are encouraged to enter into value-based payment arrangements and help patients receive high-quality, coordinate care.

augusta care partners is an accountable care organization (aco) based in rural virginia that represents a strong partnership between independent physician practices and a community hospital with employed providers. we are currently in our second agreement period as a track 1 aco in the medicare shared savings program (mssp).
it is important to note that while our aco has not yet achieved shared savings, we have maintained quality scores in the top quartile of all mssp acos and, at the same time, have sustained one of the lowest cost-per-beneficiary rates across all mssp acos. these results can be directly tied to significant investments in improving coordination of care and our team of providers being committed to generating positive outcomes for medicare beneficiaries in our community. as a participating augusta care partners provider, i feel it is important to voice my opinion on a few key points in the mssp proposed rule, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizations pathways to success.
providing an opportunity to choose prospective attribution in both the basic and enhanced tracks is a significant improvement. our aco has been challenged by the uncertainty of preliminary prospective beneficiary assignment with retrospective reconciliation. having the option to definitively know our attributed patient panel at the beginning of the year offers some much-needed stability and helps guide the appropriate allocation of our acos finite resources.
the flexibility offered by the snf waiver is a huge benefit. i appreciate that cms is expanding access to this important program feature.
i am hopeful that the 5 year agreement periods offered in both the basic and enhanced tracks will create increased predictability in the program. it is also a welcome change to have risk scores updated annually for the acos total population, instead of differentiating between newly assigned and continuously assigned beneficiaries. i am concerned, however, that limiting the risk adjustment to +/- 3% over that 5 year agreement period will not protect providers who serve our most medically complicated patients. medicare beneficiaries can experience significant changes in health status over 5 years, and those changes may not be adequately addressed by the proposed methodology. our aco has been challenged by a benchmark that does not reflect the health of our population. we have worked hard to understand the mssps complex benchmarking rules and to raise awareness about the importance of coding specificity to care coordination. i am concerned that, despite our demonstrated track record of low cost and high quality, the +/- 3% cap will disadvantage our aco by continuing to incorrectly capture the health status of our beneficiaries, making shared savings unattainable.
its no secret that the abstraction of quality metrics is an onerous process, and i am encouraged by the current administrations efforts to reduce reporting burden for providers. i am also a strong advocate for transparency in scoring. should cms choose to increase the number of claims-based measures, it would be extremely helpful to provide user-friendly, actionable reports that detail the aco-specific data used to calculate specific measure performance.
i am concerned about how the enhanced notification requirements will impact my office workflow and efficiency. it will be challenging to add one more piece of paper to the stack of important documents my patients are asked to review and acknowledge at each visit. also, while i appreciate the option of providing beneficiary incentives, the administrative burden of implementation and tracking would likely create additional frustration for staff and add expense to my offices operations.
thank you for taking my comments into consideration as you work to streamline the mssp model. i look forward to seeing continued improvements in the coming years that will benefit my patients and allow me and my fellow aco participants to focus on providing high-quality and efficient care to our community.
sincerely,
cynthia allen, md
blue ridge pathologists
augusta care partners

it is my opinion that the proposed rule pathways to success primarily focuses on moving those accountable care organizations (acos) that are currently in track 1 to a risk-based track. however, it does not in any way promote those aco participants that have voluntarily taken the leap to take part in the medicare share savings program at the highest level of risk (track 3).

it is my opinion that those acos that are currently participating as a track 3 aco, should be given the following options:

1.participate in the basic track as all other acos
2.be given an extension of the current agreement period
3.reduce agreement period (3-years), for first renewal period of current track 3 acos

thank you for your consideration.

banner health network, based in phoenix, az participated in pioneer aco for all 5 years before moving to mssp track 3 aco. participating in our mssp aco is more than 500 clinicians, both independent and employed, with a medicare beneficiary alignment of approximately 50,000. our aco in northern colorado, banner network colorado, is in its second year of mssp track 2, with approximately 12,000 aligned medicare beneficiaries. our parent company, banner health, owns 28 hospitals including 3 academic medical centers, as well as urgent care centers, ambulatory surgical centers, and several physician groups including pcp and specialists.
we understand the reasons cms wants to encourage acos to take on more financial risk. we hope that sharing our insights helps cms in this goal. one general comment we have regarding the push to risk is that for a responsible aco board to be comfortable with the financial investments of an aco model, they need reliable and timely information. specifically, they need more reliable and timely financial forecasting tools. this has been a challenge for our two acos and it is likely for other acos. for a new aco that is looking to move up in risk annually, they need to make certain business decisions for staffing and resourcing prior to the next performance year. unless cms can provide faster insight on reasonably accurate financial performance, you may not see the desired risk acceptance. for example, an aco applying in spring of 2019 (assuming a normal application cycle) for a january 2020 start would not have any idea of their financial benchmark until april 2020; and that is only the preliminary benchmark. the final benchmark does not arrive until october (2020, in this example). furthermore, we experienced a material difference between preliminary, final and settled benchmarks, and the quarterly e&u reports did not do much to clarify our actual performance. the swing in our forecast, between the changing benchmarks and the updated e&u reports showed a very wide variance. explaining that to a board of directors does not invoke confidence. for some acos, they are not able or willing to tolerate that kind of financial volatility.
as an entity that also explored bundled payment for care improvement advanced (bpci-a), we were thankful to cms centers for medicare and medicaid innovation (cmmi) for the provision of target prices during the application period in summer of 2018 so that we could make an informed decision on our ability to meet that financial expectation before investing thousands of dollars and resources for staffing. we would like to see cms provide a benchmark range to an applying aco during the application cycle so the aco can also assess their readiness and likelihood of success.

we understand the reasons cms wants to encourage acos to take on more financial risk.  we hope that sharing our insights helps cms in this goal. one general comment we have regarding the push to risk is that for a responsible aco board to be comfortable with the financial investments of an aco model, they need reliable and timely information.  specifically, they need more reliable and timely financial forecasting tools. this has been a challenge for our two acos and it is likely for other acos.  for a new aco that is looking to move up in risk annually, they need to make certain business decisions for staffing and resourcing prior to the next performance year.  unless cms can provide faster insight on reasonably accurate financial performance, you may not see the desired risk acceptance. for example, an aco applying in spring of 2019 (assuming a normal application cycle) for a january 2020 start would not have any idea of their financial benchmark until april 2020; and that is only the preliminary benchmark.  the final benchmark does not arrive until october (2020, in this example). furthermore, we experienced a material difference between preliminary, final and settled benchmarks, and the quarterly e&u reports did not do much to clarify our actual performance. the swing in our forecast, between the changing benchmarks and the updated e&u reports showed a loss more than $14 million for 2017, when ultimately, we were far less than that and within our risk corridor. explaining that to a board of directors does not invoke confidence. for some acos, they are not able or willing to tolerate that kind of financial volatility.
as an entity that also explored bundled payment for care improvement â advanced (bpci-a), we were thankful to cms centers for medicare and medicaid innovation (cmmi) for the provision of target prices during the application period in summer of 2018 so that we could make an informed decision on our ability to meet that financial expectation before investing thousands of dollars and resources for staffing.  we would like to see cms provide a benchmark range to an applying aco during the application cycle so the aco can also assess their readiness and likelihood of success.
below we make comments specific to sections of the proposed rule.
beneficiary incentives (page 309, section c, 2nd paragraph).
in this section, cms proposes: âwe mirror the language in the proposed regulation text noting that âa qualifying service is a primary care serviceâ a defined in 425.20, with respect to which coinsurance applies under part b.â
most acos agree that the best practice for beneficiary engagement in wellness is to encourage them to utilize the medicare annual wellness visit (awv). this allows for a face to face with their primary doctor where the doctor and patient can discuss beneficiary concerns, provide or refer for preventative services, check on at-risk conditions such as diabetes, and establish a care plan. many acos that promote this visit notice an improvement in mssp quality measures.  however, cms does not apply a co-insurance to the awv, which, according to this definition, would disallow this important visit to be the focus of an incentive plan.  please consider a revised definition of âqualifying serviceâ so that incenting the awv can be an option.
program measures and quality data â part d (p 434-443
we understand the logic of aligning programs and initiatives, but at this time, bringing in quality measures for opioids does not seem like the right decision. the cms focus right now is to get acos to take on more risk, so let them focus on the key drivers that impact their population in their community, instead of side-tracking with this potentially large initiative that will no doubt take resources for which most acos do not currently have funding. each aco is unique in their participant mix, their resources, their aligned population, and their region. what works for one does not always work for another. bringing in quality measures that are this specific will detract acos from focusing on what does work for them.
as an alternative, cms could provide acos with learning webinars for provider and aco education, and various tools and data for acos to incorporate into their current structure for care management and patient engagement. to augment this effort, please consider allowing access to part 2 data so acos can create appropriate and relevant clinical models to address the opioid situation.
aco-11 and promoting interoperability (page 443-454).
in general, we have no concerns about the difference between 50% or 75% requirement between the different tracks.  it is reasonable to expect the higher tracks to have a higher cehrt adoption rate. however, we would ask that you delay this change because of inaccurate results from quality payment program. acos receive a supplemental aco11 file with their annual settlement packet. in the packet we received in august 2018 for the 2017 performance year, our aco11 file was incomplete, in that it did not contain all of our participating providers; in fact, it was missing about half.  due to the incomplete data, we were not able to measure where we truly are in terms of percentages for what is now called promoting interoperability.
it would be great for a track 3 (enhanced) aco to tell a participant that they no longer need to sign into qpp and attest to promoting interoperability, specifically because the other quality reporting is done at the aco level and pi is the only category that requires a participant-initiated submission. however, without detail on how an aco would confirm this requirement for the purposes of an attestation, we are concerned that moving to an aco certification process may inadvertently place the aco in a non-compliant situation. is the standard for confirming a participantâs status simple enough for an aco to confirm? many acos have participants that are on different ehrs. our aco would be confident in attesting to the ehr used by our employed clinicians, but we would have to do a separate analysis for each of our independent practices. the cehrt definition at 42 cfr 414.1305 seems to be more than an aco could confidently assess on their own. for example, we donât know that we have the expertise to say that any given participant has a sufficient security plan [42 cfr 414.1305 (1)(ii)(a) (7)(c)]. we would ask that you better clarify the operational expectations for this attestation so that acos can confirm they are able to confidently attest.
regarding the retiring of aco11 in favor of an attestation â if a new entity wants to join mssp and is willing to start in basic track e or enhanced, during application, the entity will have to survey every participant to ensure they meet for the acoâs attesting to cehrt.  this will add to the time investment of an application, especially for an entity with a high number of independent participants.  it might be reasonable to allow track e and enhanced to come in at 50% for the first performance year and then go to 75% in the second; it would be the equivalent of the pay for reporting in the quality measures in performance year 1.

 dear administrator verma: thank you for this opportunity to provide comments on the medicare shared savings program (mssp). as an electronic health records developer based in verona, wisconsin, we at epic have significant experience supporting accountable care organizations (acos) using our software as they participate in mssp, as well as in other cms quality reporting programs. our experience informs our feedback here on the following specific proposals by cms:
ii.a.4.c proposals for permitting annual election of beneficiary assignment methodology

re: cms-1701-p, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizationsâpathways to success
dear administrator verma,
on behalf of our communityâs accountable care organization, community health provider alliance (chpa), we would like to take this opportunity to express the interest federally qualified health centers (referred to here as fqhcs, or âhealth centersâ) have in the medicare shared savings program (mssp).
our aco is a not-for-profit community-based organization comprised solely of fqhcs in colorado.  our health centers are non-profit, community-directed providers that serve as the primary medical home for 790,000 patients in our state, including more than 1 in 7 coloradoans.
we welcome the opportunity to respond to cmsâ pathways to success nprm.  while we believe the proposed rule includes important steps toward increased success, there are several areas where we raise caution and seek clarification.  in summary, our comments will focus on the following areas:
health centers are important partners in accountable care arrangements, producing cost savings for the system and enhanced quality of care for beneficiaries and look forward to continuing this work together.
cms should invest in a more gradual pathway to increased levels of financial risk for low-revenue provider-led accountable care organizations (acos), with consideration made to those acos comprised solely of fqhcs.
many fqhcs, because they provide care to some of the most underserved communities in the country, require additional investment to prepare for two-sided risk arrangements.
increased flexibility in the ability to provide telehealth services will support health centers participating in the pathways to success program.
a more appropriate benchmarking process will support participating health centers in delivering the best care for the vulnerable populations they serve.
cms should be mindful of inadvertently causing âcherry-pickingâ of patients by allowing acos to provide beneficiary incentives.
we are in opposition to a few key aspects of the recent proposed pathways to success rule, in particular the agency's proposal to cut acos shared savings rates below 50 percent, reduce the time in a shared savings-only model from six to two years, and application of a +/- 3 percent risk adjustment cap across an extended agreement period.
these proposed changes will harm patients and providers by limiting improvements in savings and quality acos provide, while slowing progress made in transitioning to value-base payments. our aco has made a significant investment in funding the operations to support the mssp, and a reduction in potential savings will greatly impact our ability to reinvest in our care models/teams and will significantly limit our ability to generate enough capital to meet the repayment mechanism requirements.  as a non-profit, low revenue aco, our aco may be forced out of the mssp because we will lack the capital required for the repayment mechanism. our initial intention was to build up that capital over the course of 6 years under the current system, but that timeline is drastically reduced with the proposed changes.
we appreciate cmsâ recognition of the additional time many provider-led acos may need to transition to higher levels of two-sided risk by allowing provider-led acos to cycle through the âbasicâ track for two agreement periods.  however, this still only allows provider-led acos two years without taking on financial risk. due to the pace of data sharing and the imperative to transform care models, we recommend cms allow provider-led acos an even more gradual pathway to two-sided risk. specifically, we suggest cms allow provider-led acos a minimum of three years in the âbasicâ track in an upside-only arrangement.
while we support incorporating regional expenditures in the benchmark established for an acoâs first agreement, we are concerned that the two proposed policies to limit the magnitude of the adjustment undermines the policy goals. as cms has recognized, the incorporation of regional expenditures provides an aco with a benchmark that is more reflective of ffs spending in the acoâs region than a benchmark based solely on the acoâs own historical expenditures. this approach creates stronger financial incentives for acos that have been successful in reducing expenditures to remain in the program, thus improving program sustainability. it also allows cms to better capture the cost experience in the acoâs region, the health status and socio-economic dynamics of the regional population, and location-specific medicare payments when compared to using national ffs expenditures.
we disagree that higher weights for the regional adjustment results in potential windfall gains to lower-cost acos. those gains are not windfalls but compensate lower-cost acos for the work invested in practices to reduce the overall costs of care for medicare beneficiaries. in fact, a lower-cost aco composed of fqhcs may have higher expenditures for primary care due to the prospective payment system (pps) methodology as compared to regional expenditures for primary care services that are generally reimbursed under the medicare fee schedule.  the risk adjustment benchmarking cap uniquely will harm our non-profit fqhc-based aco. in the past, our coding processes were fairly rudimentary which is evidenced by our unusually low risk adjustment scores and unusually low benchmarks given the patient population we serve.  our networkâs understanding of risk adjustment is relatively new, but weâve implemented coding improvement efforts to more accurately reflect the acuity of our patients and to better capture hcc codes annually.  the proposed limit of +/-3% would mitigate our efforts to improve in these crucial areas which impact our ability to be successful in the mssp.
on the other hand, we support a number of proposals in the rule and encourage cms to finalize its proposals to: 1) move to five-year agreement periods; 2) reduce burdens related to quality reporting; 3) expand the use of waivers for telehealth and skilled nursing facility stays; and 4) provide flexibility with choosing assignment methodology regardless of risk model.
the proposed provisions related to allowing acos to provide and be reimbursed for telehealth services, will help health centers continue to meet the unique needs of their communities in the most cost-efficient ways. however, while the preamble to the proposed rule outlines the process for which a provider can be reimbursed for his or her telehealth work, it is not clear how this new provision will impact health centers.  health centers are currently limited to serving as originating sites only and are not able to provide or be reimbursed as a distant site in medicare.  the preamble and proposed rule make reference to âphysicians and providersâ using the acoâs tin, however it is not clear if this provision will allow health centers to fully participate in the telehealth provisions.   we encourage cms to clarify the language in the proposed rule in order to clearly allow health centers to provide this valuable service through their work in an aco.
fqhcs are unique in that they are both required by federal law and committed to serving everyone that seeks care and must serve communities most in need of care. they turn no patient away, regardless of income, insurance status, risk, or complexity. this open-door policy is a defining feature of the health center mission of providing quality, affordable access to care to all who need it. additionally, beneficiariesâ freedom of choice is an important way for practices and payers, including medicare, to gauge practice effectiveness and the demand for access to health care services in specific communities. should cms decide to allow acos to incentivize beneficiaries, it should implement safeguards to ensure that higher-revenue acos do not inadvertently attract healthier patients, potentially skewing quality metrics and leaving sicker patients with fewer options.
thank you again for your work on behalf of patients and providers to advance value-based payment. we appreciate your interest in sustaining the success of medicare acos and creating an environment where providers are encouraged to enter into value-based payment arrangements and help patients receive high-quality, coordinate care.

 cms has proposed to redesign the mssp so as to encourage participation in successful pathways, while removing components of the program which serve to hinder the transition to value-based care. pathways to success proposes to advance risk-sharing and while working to maintain the incentive to participate in the model. several of the major provisions touch on issues core to the work of the bpc health project. the bpc health project developed a white paper in january 2015 specifically aimed at improving acos!. many of our positions regarding this value-based model continue to be relevant.

 the current flexibilities afforded acos have led to a majority of one-sided risk arrangements. however, the cms review of aco performance over the past several years has shown that acos bearing two- sided risk, and those that were low-volume (generally, physician-led), were most successful in generating cost savings while improving quality. in fact, acos bearing only upside risk incurred costs greater than the benchmark. based on the success of the track 1+ model designed by the innovation center and reluctance of current track 1 acos to accept the high level of risk in track 2 and 3, cms has proposed a redesign of the pathways. the current aco pathways would be retired and replaced with a basic îãâ£glideîãâ¥ path and an enhanced pathway, each with a minimum agreement period of 5 years.
 the pathway of an aco will be determined by the level of experience in the model and its time in an upside-only arrangement will be minimized. the basic path would begin as upside-only risk for a maximum of two years, followed by a yearly, progressive increase in downside-risk responsibility. the highest basic level and the enhanced track, based on the current track 3, would qualify as advanced apms under the quality payment program. speeding up the path to full risk will decrease unnecessary spending, while quality measures continue to ensure efficiency and sufficient provision of care. bpc strongly supports the move to shared risk as a means to significant savings and meaningful quality improvements.

 along with this proposal to increase risk, cms introduced a decrease in potential shared savings. shared savings in the upside-risk year(s), would be twenty-five percent, half of the current track 1 model. the current fifty percent shared savings would be applied for acos at the maximum basic risk level. the decrease in shared savings may discourage some program participants. the new potential returns, when weigh against upfront investments, may be of concern to participants. this is a particularly salient issue for experienced acos that would be placed in the enhanced track. however, the protection of the medicare trust through cost-saving measures must be balanced with program attrition. bpc encourages the administration to seek ways to minimize attrition, while remaining committed to full risk.

dear administrator verma,

it is important to note that while our aco has not yet achieved shared savings, we have maintained quality scores in the top quartile of all mssp acos and, at the same time, have sustained one of the lowest cost-per-beneficiary rates across all mssp acos. these results can be directly tied to significant investments in improving coordination of care and our team of providers being committed to generating positive outcomes for medicare beneficiaries in our community. as a participating augusta care partners provider, i feel it is important to voice my opinion on a few key points in the mssp proposed rule, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizations pathways to success.
providing an opportunity to choose prospective attribution in both the basic and enhanced tracks is a significant improvement. our aco has been challenged by the uncertainty of preliminary prospective beneficiary assignment with retrospective reconciliation. having the option to definitively know our attributed patient panel at the beginning of the year offers some much-needed stability and helps guide the appropriate allocation of our acos finite resources.
the flexibility offered by the snf waiver is a huge benefit. i appreciate that cms is expanding access to this important program feature.
i am hopeful that the 5 year agreement periods offered in both the basic and enhanced tracks will create increased predictability in the program. it is also a welcome change to have risk scores updated annually for the acos total population, instead of differentiating between newly assigned and continuously assigned beneficiaries. i am concerned, however, that limiting the risk adjustment to +/- 3% over that 5 year agreement period will not protect providers who serve our most medically complicated patients. medicare beneficiaries can experience significant changes in health status over 5 years, and those changes may not be adequately addressed by the proposed methodology. our aco has been challenged by a benchmark that does not reflect the health of our population. we have worked hard to understand the mssps complex benchmarking rules and to raise awareness about the importance of coding specificity to care coordination. i am concerned that, despite our demonstrated track record of low cost and high quality, the +/- 3% cap will disadvantage our aco by continuing to incorrectly capture the health status of our beneficiaries, making shared savings unattainable.
its no secret that the abstraction of quality metrics is an onerous process, and i am encouraged by the current administrations efforts to reduce reporting burden for providers. i am also a strong advocate for transparency in scoring. should cms choose to increase the number of claims-based measures, it would be extremely helpful to provide user-friendly, actionable reports that detail the aco-specific data used to calculate specific measure performance.
i am concerned about how the enhanced notification requirements will impact my office workflow and efficiency. it will be challenging to add one more piece of paper to the stack of important documents my patients are asked to review and acknowledge at each visit. also, while i appreciate the option of providing beneficiary incentives, the administrative burden of implementation and tracking would likely create additional frustration for staff and add expense to my offices operations.
thank you for taking my comments into consideration as you work to streamline the mssp model. i look forward to seeing continued improvements in the coming years that will benefit my patients and allow me and my fellow aco participants to focus on providing high-quality and efficient care to our community.

sincerely,

augusta care partners

0220:
2019 agreements already cms-approved and signed

we are a 2016 track 1 physician-led aco and are very concerned about having the timeline changed after all of our existing and new participants for 2019 have already signed new agreements approved by the cms.

current regulations state track 1 acos are limited to two agreement periods under a one-sided model before transitioning to a two-sided model beginning with their third agreement period. when we entered the final year of our initial agreement period, we created a new three-year agreement following these current regulations. we made significant changes for 2019, including higher expectations to achieve results, and completely changed our shared savings distribution model to meet current measure requirements.

we submitted our revised sample 2019 agreement to our cms coordinator and it was approved in may, 2018. we then spent the next two months meeting with every existing and new practice to explain the new agreement and expectations for our second agreement period. at this point, we have:
-69 existing practices that have already signed the new cms-approved three-year track 1 agreement, representing some 20,000 beneficiaries.
-another 16 new practices with 129 providers have also signed these new 2019 agreements, which would be effective january 1, 2019.
-new agreements were submitted with change requests in aco ms based on the published timeline.

therefore, our entire group of participants is now ready to move forward under more stringent requirements for even better results in the next three-year agreement period as outlined in current regulations.

if the rules change after all of these physicians have already signed the agreements that cms approved, the implications are serious.
-under the proposed rule, it appears that our initial agreement would be extended through june, 2019. this means existing practices would be operating under a different agreement than the new practices, which means two different sets of expectations and two different distribution models. or we will have to go back to every practice to modify the agreement at a time when we need to be focused on getting results!
-our 2019 mssp-approved participant agreement clearly outlines that we are a track 1 aco, and the distribution model is based on the shared savings program as outlined in the published cms regulations with a 50% shared savings. changing either of these key components as outlined in the proposed rule is significant enough to require revised participant agreements. the time and cost spent on revising agreements and revisiting 85 different practices will add significant burdens on the aco and its participants, and delay the execution of many initiatives underway to produce results this year.
-our new participants expect to begin working with us in january, 2019, under a new three-year agreement. they did so with the understanding we can help them report a full year of data for mips. the implications in filing mips for these independent practices are complex based on these new bifurcated timelines.

changing the rules mid-stream when agreements have already been approved, signed and submitted is an unreasonable burden when we have so much to accomplish in the coming months. this will clearly impact our ability to meet goals.

we ask that cms keep the current program in place, finalize these rules and then roll them out in advance of the next program period. this would allow acos to transition their participants into revised contracts, policies and procedures in an orderly fashion.
0221:
the proposed rule states one-sided model acos, which are not accountable for sharing in losses, have actually increased medicare spending relative to their benchmarks.

this is misleading because a small group of poorly performing acos negatively skew the results of the group. we agree that perpetually poor performers should be counseled or cut from the program so their results do not negatively offset the work of those of us achieving meaningful results.

in the 2017 data just published:
-eight acos had costs that exceeded benchmarks by more than $20 million. those eight acos alone were responsible for $251,000,000 of the losses under the mssp. (column s, benchmark minus expenditures.)
-a total of 23 acos had costs greater than $10 million over benchmark, for a total of $458.7 million in cost to the program.
-so of the 472 acos with 2017 results listed, 5% of the acos were responsible for 42% of the negative impact on the program. (sum of losses by bottom 23 acos / sum of column s benchmark minus expenditures.) we understand the need to address challenges with these acos.

and yet there were 284 acos that did reduce costs compared to benchmark in 2017. in the data just published, those acos achieved more than $2 billion in savings. like our aco, they are performing well and doing exactly what the program was designed to do.

we are a 2016 track 1 aco. in our first two years, we have:
-saved the medicare trust fund over $2.5 million.
-helped our providers achieve a quality score in the mid-90s.
-set up the infrastructure, invested in software systems, and kicked off a population health program on a broad scale.
-developed a network of nearly 400 engaged, independent providers including many in extremely poor and rural areas. our participating providers have said we are making them better doctors. they are catching health problems earlier and reducing exacerbations.

why force acos who are successfully meeting program goals into at-risk models based on a small percentage of those who have not been successful? how many acos will be forced to close down when they are just on the verge, or are already achieving, program goals?

every aco is different. every community they serve is different. physician-led acos like ours are preforming better than those led by hospitals. making broad changes as outlined in the proposed rule based on the poor performance of a small percentage of acos is quite likely to cause great harm to the meaningful work underway.

we recommend you focus on performance. for those acos who are struggling, provide guidance or remove them from the program. but please dont punish the ones who are having success by changing the rules when the program is just getting momentum.
0222:
investment by rural physicians

we are a 2016 track 1 physician-led aco that operates with independent practices in rural, under-served areas. we have created meaningful savings and improved quality in both years of operation.

-we have invested countless hours and approximately $2 million to get to this point.
-cms approved our three-year track 1 agreement in may and our 80+ independent practices have signed the agreements. and just when we are moving forward into our second performance period, the proposed rule would invalidate all of our agreements and force us to stop our work and determine if we will have the money to move forward under a two-sided model.
-a small group of rural providers took a leap of faith by investing in this aco for the first three-year agreement and have assumed responsibility for a line of credit based on anticipated shared savings in the next three-year period. the terms were based on the potential of 50% shared savings.
-not only does this proposed rule cut the potential return in half, we will also be expected to set up an escrow account or surety bond, requiring an even greater investment. the owners do not have any additional funds to invest.
-the rule indicates that this repayment mechanism would potentially have to cover a 7-year period five year agreement plus a 24-month tail period. what would an independent rural doctor use as collateral or a loan guarantee for a seven-year loan? why would a lender approve a seven-year loan when they realize rules can be dramatically changed after contracts have already been approved and signed? we are not hospital-owned and we dont have a wealthy parent organization to set up this mechanism.

if cms moves forward with this proposed rule -- changing the terms of our agreement when it was already approved and the contracts have all been signed -- it is clearly going to make many physicians question the integrity of the program. why should they agree to go at risk when the rules can be changed after agreements have already been approved by cms?

if the owners and participants do not have funding for an escrow account and we are forced to shut down the aco, all that we have invested to this point will be wiped out. the owners will not have a chance to recoup their investment, and future anticipated savings will be lost.

several of our independent rural physicians have already said they are ready to retire, opt out of medicare or simply do the minimum required for mips if the aco were not there to guide them in this transition in the way care is provided.

the aco is playing a critical role in helping these poor, rural communities. we are careful stewards of the healthcare dollar and in only two years have improved quality and reduced healthcare expenditures for the patients we serve.

we have honored our commitment in making the program successful by reducing costs and improving quality. its vital that cms honor the commitments you have made to our physicians by allowing us to continue under the agreement you have already approved for the next three-year agreement period.

0224:
beneficiary notification

adding a requirement for physicians to notify beneficiaries about aco participation at their first visit of each calendar year is overly burdensome for a busy primary care practice. this means that in addition to providing each beneficiary with a document that the practice is part of an aco, a staff member must be available to explain it, answer questions and document the interaction.

we remember the problems that occurred when patients originally received the lengthy letter from cms notifying them of aco participation. it caused confusion and created unfounded concerns about patient privacy. the front desk staff members fielded calls every day from anxious patients.

posting a notice and making copies available to those who ask has worked well this puts patients over paperwork. giving out notices and explaining them to every medicare beneficiary at a busy front desk or in an exam room is something else. many of our providers in rural areas see 40-60 patients a day. there are routinely 4-8 people waiting in line to check in or out. this rule would add a task that does not improve the quality of care provided, but increases valuable time and cost.

and when those patients then ask the physician to explain this document also and they will it takes even more time away from acute and preventive care.

the proposed rule also states the aco would be required to establish a method for tracking beneficiary notification. that means ehr modifications, which adds cost to the practice and are yet another distraction from patient care.

the current regulations with signs posted and copies made available is sufficient. this proposed additional notification adds nothing to the quality of care being provided. nor does it add to transparency beneficiaries tell us they already assume health information is being shared among their care providers.

also, the notifications absolutely should not mention beneficiary incentives because not all acos will have the funding to provide these. for those acos able to provide these incentives, a language template and guidelines would be appropriate. but it is unfair to tell a beneficiary that incentives may be available, but they cant access them because the particular aco does not have the funding to offer them.

dear administrator verma,

augusta care partners is an accountable care organization (aco) based in rural virginia that represents
a strong partnership between independent physician practices and a community hospital with employed
providers. we are currently in our second agreement period as a track 1 aco in the medicare shared
savings program (mssp).

it is important to note that while our aco has not yet achieved shared savings, we have maintained
quality scores in the top quartile of all mssp acos and, at the same time, have sustained one of the
lowest cost-per-beneficiary rates across all mssp acos. these results can be directly tied to significant
investments in improving coordination of care and our team of providers being committed to generating
positive outcomes for medicare beneficiaries in our community. as a participating augusta care
partners provider, i feel it is important to voice my opinion on a few key points in the mssp proposed
rule, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizations pathways
to success.

providing an opportunity to choose prospective attribution in both the basic and enhanced
tracks is a significant improvement. our aco has been challenged by the uncertainty of
preliminary prospective beneficiary assignment with retrospective reconciliation. having the
option to definitively know our attributed patient panel at the beginning of the year offers some
much-needed stability and helps guide the appropriate allocation of our acos finite resources.

the flexibility offered by the snf waiver is a huge benefit. i appreciate that cms is expanding
access to this important program feature.

i am hopeful that the 5 year agreement periods offered in both the basic and enhanced tracks
will create increased predictability in the program. it is also a welcome change to have risk
scores updated annually for the acos total population, instead of differentiating between
newly assigned and continuously assigned beneficiaries. i am concerned, however, that
limiting the risk adjustment to +/- 3% over that 5 year agreement period will not protect
providers who serve our most medically complicated patients. medicare beneficiaries can
experience significant changes in health status over 5 years, and those changes may not be
adequately addressed by the proposed methodology. our aco has been challenged by a
benchmark that does not reflect the health of our population. we have worked hard to
understand the mssps complex benchmarking rules and to raise awareness about the
importance of coding specificity to care coordination. i am concerned that, despite our
demonstrated track record of low cost and high quality, the +/- 3% cap will disadvantage our
aco by continuing to incorrectly capture the health status of our beneficiaries, making shared
savings unattainable.

its no secret that the abstraction of quality metrics is an onerous process, and i am encouraged
by the efforts to reduce reporting burden for providers. i am also a
strong advocate for transparency in scoring. should cms choose to increase the number of
claims-based measures, it would be extremely helpful to provide user-friendly, actionable
reports that detail the aco-specific data used to calculate specific measure performance.

i am concerned about how the enhanced notification requirements will impact my office
workflow and efficiency. it will be challenging to add one more piece of paper to the stack of
important documents my patients are asked to review and acknowledge at each visit. also,
while i appreciate the option of providing beneficiary incentives, the administrative burden of
implementation and tracking would likely create additional frustration for staff and add expense
to my offices operations.

thank you for taking my comments into consideration as you work to streamline the mssp model. i look
forward to seeing continued improvements in the coming years that will benefit my patients and allow
me and my fellow aco participants to focus on providing high-quality and efficient care to our
community.

sincerely,

alexandra geneser, psyd
valleymed psych
augusta care partners

good morning:

the medicare shared savings track has been very beneficial for patients and hospitals in rural america. it is my
understanding that mssp rural programs saved medicare 82 million dollars in 2016 and we have been improving
since that time. our original investment was just over $2.0 million and we have just begun to recoup some of that in

programs such as proposed by cms. one size does not fit all especially in the risk of an aco. we are asking you to
consider a rural model that allows the no risk program for 5 years. please consider this request as many rural aco's
will not continue or start under the proposed model by cms. why would everyone want to lose the savings that are
achievable in a rural aco model? it seems counterproductive to us. i will let the officers of our mssp attach the
financial information for your review. thank you for listening.
