i am the chief executive officer of lincoln county hospital, which is located in a frontier county in northcentral kansas. lincoln county hospital and its two rural health clinics operate in a federal hpsa for an under-served low income population. we are also a national health service corps site. we participate in the kansas clinical improvement collaborative (kcic).

i am commenting in support of the kcic's proposal for a rural track accountable care organization.

kcic delivers value to its participants by supporting local implementation of acute and
ambulatory evidence-based guidelines, providing chronic care management services,
coordinating the care continuum, leading smarter spending initiatives, performing data analytics,
and producing performance dashboards. through its governing body and committees (which are
comprised of representatives from each participant), kcic provides a forum for rural providers
to share experiences and overcome challenges in delivery system reform.

we are deeply concerned that the elimination of the shared savings-only model will force rural
providers to abandon the mssp just as we are embracing the model. initially, the mssp
attracted few rural providers due to their small populations and lack of resources. with
appropriate incentives and supports, however, many of us now are participating in
multi-community networks focused on quality and smarter spending. the mssp has provided a
vehicle to accomplish what previously had seemed impossible: independent rural providers
collaborating to improve the health of their respective communities.

as a practical matter, most rural acos will not be able to fund the required repayment
mechanism that is proposed in the current rule under consideration. given its size and adjusted historical benchmark, kcic would have to secure a $2.3 million letter of credit or surety bond or place that amount in an escrow account. kcic itself does not have these resources and its participants small rural hospitals, rural health clinics, and
federally qualified health centers likely will not be able to bear this additional expense.

developing a rural track aco gives rural providers an opportunity to transition from volume based care to value based care that your new models would deny to us. i urge you to keep and/or develop an mssp for rural providers by adopting the rural track we are proposing

regards,

steven l. granzow, ceo
lincoln county hospital
lincoln, ks

dear administrator verma,

the accountable care organizations that we have been associated with since 2012, atlantic accountable care organization and optimus healthcare partners, have been successful in reducing costs and improving quality during our tenure in the medicare shared savings program. optimus healthcare partners a 2012 starter and one that would be consider a high revenue aco in the new program, achieved shared savings in every one of the five years it has been in the program, totaling $59 million dollars since inception. our atlantic accountable care organization, a hospital owned aco was successful in achieving shared savings in 2015, and saving medicare in 2016, as well as improving quality.
one of our areas of concern in the proposed rule is the fact that cms is moving back to a beneficiary notification requirement that will place a tremendous administrative burden on our respective accountable care organizations from both a cost and human resources standpoint. we urge you to reconsider this and maintain the program in its current state of an opt out notification for data sharing and the posting of a aco participation notification in practice offices.
we write in opposition to other key aspects of the recent centers for medicare & medicaid services (cms) proposed "pathways to success" rule on the medicare shared savings program, in particular the agency's proposal to cut accountable care organizations' (acos') shared savings rates below 50 percent, reduce the time in a shared savings-only model from six to two years, and introduce early termination policies based on spending that is slightly higher than benchmarks. we also urge cms to modify the proposed application of a +/- 3 percent risk adjustment cap across an extended agreement period by increasing that to +/- 5 percent.
we have extensive commercial aco relationships as well and we have always considered a payer provider partnership a 50:50 proposition. requiring non-risk bearing aco's to have only a 25% shared savings opportunity is not a partnership.
acos have been in the forefront of transforming physician practice patterns with a reach far beyond the mssp program alone. it has fostered the patient centered medical home model of care, and allowed for greater coordination of care between providers. the proposal in the new rule particularly around, shortening the time to risk and offering the lowest savings opportunities will gut the program of new applicants, and cause a flight to other alternative models such as medicare advantage and commercial value-based contracts to the detriment of the traditional medicare beneficiary.
another area of concern is the mssp decision to define high revenue versus low revenue aco's, and force the former more rapidly into downside risk tracks. having managed both a physician led organization and a hospital led aco, we have from experience recognized that the high revenue aco's are actually more difficult to move forward down the risk glide path, because inherently they become a less cohesive group. high revenue acos as defined, have invested heavily on developing the infrastructure in both technology platforms and care management to help their acos eventually succeed. we urge cms to remove the distinction between high revenue and low revenue aco's.


on the other hand, we support a number of proposals in the rule and encourage cms to finalize its proposals to: 1) move to five-year agreement periods; 2) introduce a more gradual glide path to risk and make the track 1+ equivalent (basic level e) permanent; 3) reduce burdens related to quality reporting; 4) expand the use of waivers for telehealth and skilled nursing facility stays especially to all tracks and 5) provide flexibility with choosing assignment methodology regardless of risk model.

thank you again for your work on behalf of patients and providers to advance value-based payment. we appreciate your interest in sustaining the success of medicare acos and creating an environment where providers are encouraged to enter into value-based payment arrangements and help patients receive high-quality, coordinate care.

 comment

 however, cms may want to consider modifying its proposal by increasing the shared savings rates in the basic track. the proposed shared savings rates in the basic track are 25 percent in level a and b, gradually increasing to 50 percent in level e. the low rates in the first years could discourage acos that might be good candidates from participating in the basic track. it might be difficult for acos to justify making the investments necessary to organize and improve care if the shared savings rates are that low. increasing the shared savings rate to 50 percent may increase participation by acos. the increase must be balanced against the risk to the medicare program of paying for random variation in the one-sided models. because the acos would only be in one- sided models for two years, there would be minimal risk to medicare from increasing the shared savings rates and doing so might encourage acos to enter the program and make the investments necessary to succeed.

 another modification cms should consider is that, if acos are taking two-sided risk, they should not be required to leave the program if they are not generating savings for one or two years. for many smaller acos (those with under 20,000 beneficiaries), there is expected to be substantial random variation in spending. in some years, they will generate shared savings and in others they will generated shared losses. if an aco is improving the efficiency of care delivery, eventually its shared savings will outweigh its shared losses. one or two years of shared losses cannot be seen as a definitive indicator of performance given the small number of beneficiaries in most acos.

 with these modifications to the proposed shared savings rates, and eliminating the requirement to achieve savings, the proposed glide path would achieve a better balance between encouraging participation by acos and creating the conditions for acos to have the incentives to succeed. the commission supports the glide path and its movement toward two-sided risk; the glide path would be strengthened by these modifications.

providing an opportunity to choose prospective attribution in both the basic and enhanced tracks is a significant improvement. our aco has been challenged by the uncertainty of preliminary prospective beneficiary assignment with retrospective reconciliation. having the option to definitively know our attributed patient panel at the beginning of the year offers some much-needed stability and helps guide the appropriate allocation of our acos finite resources.

1.typically, in a risk bearing contract, the payor or the aco has the ability to manage utilization and access to specialists. as the shared savings program product is an open nearly all inclusive network without referral requirements, acos lack the basic ability to manage utilization, to initiate referrals and control spend.
2.an aco should be awarded based on its ability to control cost, not just lower cost. the concept that an aco can continuously generate shared savings at a rate of 2% each year, for five years is erroneous. in addition, an aco that produces 1% savings a year for three years, should be rewarded, especially when compared to trend increases.
3.regional benchmarking should be a bigger percentage of the formulas as healthcare is a local phenomenon.

5.mips payment adjustments should not count as part of the cost for an aco this is counterintuitive.
6.the proposed 25% shared savings in the first 2 years of the basic glide path is not enough to cover the overhead that acos have to implement the programs to make mssp successful.
7.applications for snf and telehealth waivers need to be concise for risk bearing entities.
8.there should be a prospective trend baseline adjustment for new high expense drugs that become available during the course of the mssp program that are not part of the baseline.

dear administrator verma,
augusta care partners is an accountable care organization (aco) based in rural virginia that represents a strong partnership between independent physician practices and a community hospital with employed providers. we are currently in our second agreement period as a track 1 aco in the medicare shared savings program (mssp).
it is important to note that while our aco has not yet achieved shared savings, we have maintained quality scores in the top quartile of all mssp acos and, at the same time, have sustained one of the lowest cost-per-beneficiary rates across all mssp acos. these results can be directly tied to significant investments in improving coordination of care and our team of providers being committed to generating positive outcomes for medicare beneficiaries in our community. as a participating augusta care partners provider, i feel it is important to voice my opinion on a few key points in the mssp proposed rule, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizations pathways to success.
providing an opportunity to choose prospective attribution in both the basic and enhanced tracks is a significant improvement. our aco has been challenged by the uncertainty of preliminary prospective beneficiary assignment with retrospective reconciliation. having the option to definitively know our attributed patient panel at the beginning of the year offers some much-needed stability and helps guide the appropriate allocation of our acos finite resources.
the flexibility offered by the snf waiver is a huge benefit. i appreciate that cms is expanding access to this important program feature.
i am hopeful that the 5 year agreement periods offered in both the basic and enhanced tracks will create increased predictability in the program. it is also a welcome change to have risk scores updated annually for the acos total population, instead of differentiating between newly assigned and continuously assigned beneficiaries. i am concerned, however, that limiting the risk adjustment to +/- 3% over that 5 year agreement period will not protect providers who serve our most medically complicated patients. medicare beneficiaries can experience significant changes in health status over 5 years, and those changes may not be adequately addressed by the proposed methodology. our aco has been challenged by a benchmark that does not reflect the health of our population. we have worked hard to understand the mssps complex benchmarking rules and to raise awareness about the importance of coding specificity to care coordination. i am concerned that, despite our demonstrated track record of low cost and high quality, the +/- 3% cap will disadvantage our aco by continuing to incorrectly capture the health status of our beneficiaries, making shared savings unattainable.
its no secret that the abstraction of quality metrics is an onerous process, and i am encouraged by the current administrations efforts to reduce reporting burden for providers. i am also a strong advocate for transparency in scoring. should cms choose to increase the number of claims-based measures, it would be extremely helpful to provide user-friendly, actionable reports that detail the aco-specific data used to calculate specific measure performance.
i am concerned about how the enhanced notification requirements will impact my office workflow and efficiency. it will be challenging to add one more piece of paper to the stack of important documents my patients are asked to review and acknowledge at each visit. also, while i appreciate the option of providing beneficiary incentives, the administrative burden of implementation and tracking would likely create additional frustration for staff and add expense to my offices operations.
thank you for taking my comments into consideration as you work to streamline the mssp model. i look forward to seeing continued improvements in the coming years that will benefit my patients and allow me and my fellow aco participants to focus on providing high-quality and efficient care to our community.
sincerely,
allison baroco, md
augusta health infectious diseases
augusta care partners

0259:
while the cms revised aco and bundled payment models reflect the current leaderships continued commitment to develop solutions that better align payment with outcomes, these solutions themselves, at present, continue to fall short of the above objectives. there are three principal reasons for why this is so and three major steps that the cms can take to revise and amend their most recent payment and performance initiatives.

first, the new programs fail to establish an alternative to the same pay-for-volume, reimbursement-driven approaches that have stagnated the industry for decades. such approaches depend on the cms reimbursing providers according to how well they deliver a set menu of services, selected by the cms bureaucracy. because the cms measures the outcomes of these services according to how much they cost providers, and not necessarily how much they benefit patients; and because these costs are assessed relative to each services corresponding fee-for-service price, the cms new payment models remain predicated on a baseline fee-for-service payment structure. in this way, the cms continues to prioritize cost over outcomes and encourages providers to do the same.

second, because these new programs are still fundamentally rooted in cost and not quality, nearly all of these programs force providers to prioritize their own reimbursements over their patients health. as a result, these new payment models reward providers for betraying their true priorities: delivering the right care, in the right setting, for the right patient, at the right time.

third, these new initiatives still severely curtail patient and provider choice, not only in terms of the services provided but also in terms of the services site. site neutral payments would allow physicians to determine the optimal location for delivering a given therapy to a given patient, unencumbered by site-contingent deviations in provider reimbursement. it is therefore a critically needed component of patient-centered care. it's also critically disturbing that many in the industry have responded so antagonistically to the cms recent site-neutral payment proposals. this overwhelmingly negative outcry reveals that the true locus of many stakeholders concerns lies not in their patients, but in their own pocketbooks. i urge the cms to reflect on the extent to which their payment models reinforce this flawed incentive structure.

i also urge the cms to realign provider incentives by applying the following changes to their current aco and bundled payment models. first, enforce rapid uptake of higher levels of risk by implementing exclusively double-sided risk models; second, encourage patient and provider flexibility through enacting site-neutral payment policies; and third, reimburse care episodes in a way that focuses on overall outcomesnot upfront costs.

the decision to prioritize outcomes over price tags, as the most meaningful measure of a care episodes success requires expanding the types of care available within a payment model. it further requires extending the time horizon for evaluating treatment outcomes. this is especially true for the cms relatively new oncology care model, whose strengths and shortcomings are emblematic of virtually all the agencys present bundled payment initiatives.

while it may seem simpler in the short term to delimit the focus or duration of a payment episode to a very narrow scope, the long-term value of these programs and the services they cover can only be accurately gauged when we can evaluate their long-term effects.

bundled pricing can work for a number of treatment episodes, but only if the cms constructs better bundles. with regard to the new ocm, for instance, a comprehensive, integrated and patient-specific cancer treatment plan should be controlled by cancer type and stage. it shouldn't be exclusively triggered by the onset of outpatient chemotherapy, and it should focus on more than just cost reductions. measuring the cost of one finite and discrete intervention against its standard fee-for-service price is not going to move us closer to a value-based model. even more fundamentally, it's not going to get us nearer to pioneering and investing in the life-saving drugs and discoveries that will eventually eradicate our most pernicious diseases.

i've written several pieces on the cms recent, and highly commendable, efforts toward payment and delivery reform. two of these pieces, published in ajmc, concern the newest ocm and aco models specifically. each article details a discrete set of problems with the programs it addresses, and each proposes a series of focused solutions. the above comments reflect several of the detailed insights contained in these articles as well as in my book, bringing value to healthcare, all of whose prescriptions are based on over 25 years of experience consulting with major stakeholders as well as newer entrants in the healthcare industry.

re: comments on pathways to success mssp proposed rule
dear administrator verma,
augusta care partners is an accountable care organization (aco) based in rural virginia that represents a strong partnership between independent physician practices and a community hospital with employed providers. we are currently in our second agreement period as a track 1 aco in the medicare shared savings program (mssp).
it is important to note that while our aco has not yet achieved shared savings, we have maintained quality scores in the top quartile of all mssp acos and, at the same time, have sustained one of the lowest cost-per-beneficiary rates across all mssp acos. these results can be directly tied to significant investments in improving coordination of care and our team of providers being committed to generating positive outcomes for medicare beneficiaries in our community. as a participating augusta care partners provider, i feel it is important to voice my opinion on a few key points in the mssp proposed rule, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizations pathways to success.
providing an opportunity to choose prospective attribution in both the basic and enhanced tracks is a significant improvement. our aco has been challenged by the uncertainty of preliminary prospective beneficiary assignment with retrospective reconciliation. having the option to definitively know our attributed patient panel at the beginning of the year offers some much-needed stability and helps guide the appropriate allocation of our acos finite resources.
the flexibility offered by the snf waiver is a huge benefit. i appreciate that cms is expanding access to this important program feature.
i am hopeful that the 5 year agreement periods offered in both the basic and enhanced tracks will create increased predictability in the program. it is also a welcome change to have risk scores updated annually for the acos total population, instead of differentiating between newly assigned and continuously assigned beneficiaries. i am concerned, however, that limiting the risk adjustment to +/- 3% over that 5 year agreement period will not protect providers who serve our most medically complicated patients. medicare beneficiaries can experience significant changes in health status over 5 years, and those changes may not be adequately addressed by the proposed methodology. our aco has been challenged by a benchmark that does not reflect the health of our population. we have worked hard to understand the mssps complex benchmarking rules and to raise awareness about the importance of coding specificity to care coordination. i am concerned that, despite our demonstrated track record of low cost and high quality, the +/- 3% cap will disadvantage our aco by continuing to incorrectly capture the health status of our beneficiaries, making shared savings unattainable.
its no secret that the abstraction of quality metrics is an onerous process, and i am encouraged by the current administrations efforts to reduce reporting burden for providers. i am also a strong advocate for transparency in scoring. should cms choose to increase the number of claims-based measures, it would be extremely helpful to provide user-friendly, actionable reports that detail the aco-specific data used to calculate specific measure performance.
i am concerned about how the enhanced notification requirements will impact my office workflow and efficiency. it will be challenging to add one more piece of paper to the stack of important documents my patients are asked to review and acknowledge at each visit. also, while i appreciate the option of providing beneficiary incentives, the administrative burden of implementation and tracking would likely create additional frustration for staff and add expense to my offices operations.
thank you for taking my comments into consideration as you work to streamline the mssp model. i look forward to seeing continued improvements in the coming years that will benefit my patients and allow me and my fellow aco participants to focus on providing high-quality and efficient care to our community.
sincerely,
donna w. markey, rn msn acnp-cs
augusta health cancer center
hematology/oncology and cancer genetics
augusta care partners

the current proposal is to cap risk score benchmark adjustments at +/- 3% from the baseline year 3 (by3) to the performance year (py) and to perform this calculation separately for each category. the current proposal would effectively apply less than a 3% overall benchmark adjustment if any of the four categories have less than a 3% increase. this means that an aco could have well over 3% increase in overall risk but have significantly less than a 3% adjustment allowed.

we recommend that the 3% cap on the risk score adjustment be applied combining all eligibility categories instead of being applied at each individual eligibility category. we believe that it is more appropriate to apply the cap at the aggregate level in order to accurately reflect the changing risk and mix of an aco's population. under this method, the overall benchmark adjustment would be +/- 3% of the combined aggregate claims experience before applying the risk adjustment.

we also believe the 3% adjustment over a 5-year performance period is too low, especially in the latter years of the agreement. population changes and changes in health status of the population could be dramatic over a five-year time-frame. 3% adjustment over that entire five year period is too low. we recommend increasing the cap in the latter years (py4 and py5) to something higher than 3% and potentially a 1% per year compound growth rate in the latter years based on the final rate in py3 with no overall cap.

cms must seriously consider options strictly for rural providers when finalizing the proposed rule (cms-1707-p). the proposed levels of risk are too high and will drive rural providers and hospitals from the mssp. rural hospitals and practices are risk averse for very good reason. operating margins are too small to allow for taking on risk. rural health runs on tight budgets and limited human and capital resources. in addition to the limited, and often negative, operating margins, rural healthcare also cares for a sicker and older medicare population. the proposed rule must create a glide path specifically for rural acos.
the proposed rule attempts to create a glide path for lower revenue aco participants to take on risk. however, the proposed basic and enhanced tracks require acos to assume levels of risk unrealistic for rural hospitals, practices and independent providers. the mssp aco program is an important model for rural america. most rural acos are a combination of rural entities. it is rare to find a rural aco comprised of only independent practices. the mssp is the only model that includes multiple aspects of the healthcare system, as opposed to other value-based models that only pertain to a single practice or organization. the mssp provides the legal framework to allow rural hospitals and providers to discuss cost and create care initiatives for the entire community while still maintaining their independence.
many rural aco participants are working to decrease costs on lower than average benchmarks and smaller attributed patient populations. it is very difficult to achieve savings with the high msr smaller acos are assigned. the sicker populations and lower benchmarks mean an increased potential for extreme variability in performance year over year. one or two beneficiaries ending up in the emergency department may mean the difference between savings and losses for a rural aco and its participants. the variability of the mssp made more variable by the proposed changes makes it unrealistic for rural hospitals, critical access hospitals, rural health clinics, federally qualified health centers and independent practices to continue participating in this program. the current proposals will create a rural-urban divide in risk-based contract participation. as currently proposed, only urban hospitals and systems will have the financial reserves to assume the proposed levels of risk.
hospital board members, especially rural hospital board members, will never approve any level of risk tied to the proposed degree of variability, particularly when tied to a decreased share in savings. rural hospitals and by extension the rural independent practices they support are unable and unwilling to assume the proposed levels of risk. cms must alter the proposed changes to provide opportunity for rural hospitals to participate in the mssp without risking the financial viability of their organization. cms committed to bringing a rural healthcare focus to cms healthcare delivery and payment reform initiatives in the rural health strategy published in early 2018. this commitment is missing from the proposed rule. rural is mentioned throughout the document but there is no discussion of a rural-specific focus on participation criteria.
rural aco participants need access to a upside only or one-sided track in the mssp. the current track 1 is the only viable opportunity for rural acos to participate in a medicare value-based model. there are other options, but the mssp aco remains the only option for independent rural healthcare organizations to work together to address the cost and quality of care. but even with this model, the potential for earning enough shared savings to build sustainable cash reserves for taking risk is non-existent.
cms must develop exclusions specific to rural acos: exclusion from the proposed basic glide path and enhanced track; exclusion from proposed schedule for moving between basic and enhanced; and, exclusion from high and low revenue designations.
cms must define rural acos as: aco shall not include a hospital as an aco participant or aco provider/supplier unless the hospital is an inpatient prospective payment system hospital with fewer than 100 beds or a critical access hospital; and, 75% or more of the acos participants are located in counties designated as rural or frontier.

 the scan foundation (foundation) welcomes the opportunity to respond to the centers for medicare & medicaid servicesâ(cms) request for comment on the proposed rule for the medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizationsâ pathways to success (cmsâ1701âp). the foundation is an independent public charity devoted to transforming care for older adults in ways that preserve dignity and encourage independence. we envision a future where high-quality, affordable health care and supports for daily living are delivered on each personâs own terms, according to that individualâs needs, values, and preferences.

 an individualâs primary clinician for alignment with an aco allows more choice, and creates space for more meaningful engagement in the aco model of care. with this change, we recommend that individuals receive notification of their ability to identify their primary care provider (and the designation process) during the first visit of the year with any provider in the aligned aco. in response to cmsâ inquiry, we also recommend these notices include clear information about aco activities that have a tangible impact on the care experience. such items could include information on care coordination, beneficiary incentive programs, and the waiver of the 3-day rule regarding skilled nursing facility coverage. informed choice for beneficiaries to opt in: we are pleased to see implementation of this option. we believe the ability to opt in will encourage beneficiary engagement and help drive demand for coordinated, value-based care within medicare fee-for-service. the challenge lies in informing people of their care choices -- providing clear information, and an easy process for opting in. by including acos in mycaremychoice.org, the foundation learned first-hand how little consumer-facing information is available. we recommend cms require acos to develop transparent, culturally competent communications for their websites to inform individuals about their potential value, as well as how to opt in. thank you for the opportunity to comment.  please feel free to contact us for any additional information.

dear administrator verma,
augusta care partners is an accountable care organization (aco) based in rural virginia that represents a strong partnership between independent physician practices and a community hospital with employed providers. we are currently in our second agreement period as a track 1 aco in the medicare shared savings program (mssp).
it is important to note that while our aco has not yet achieved shared savings, we have maintained quality scores in the top quartile of all mssp acos and, at the same time, have sustained one of the lowest cost-per-beneficiary rates across all mssp acos. these results can be directly tied to significant investments in improving coordination of care and our team of providers being committed to generating positive outcomes for medicare beneficiaries in our community. as a participating augusta care partners provider, i feel it is important to voice my opinion on a few key points in the mssp proposed rule, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizations pathways to success.
providing an opportunity to choose prospective attribution in both the basic and enhanced tracks is a significant improvement. our aco has been challenged by the uncertainty of preliminary prospective beneficiary assignment with retrospective reconciliation. having the option to definitively know our attributed patient panel at the beginning of the year offers some much-needed stability and helps guide the appropriate allocation of our acos finite resources.
the flexibility offered by the snf waiver is a huge benefit. i appreciate that cms is expanding access to this important program feature.
i am hopeful that the 5 year agreement periods offered in both the basic and enhanced tracks will create increased predictability in the program. it is also a welcome change to have risk scores updated annually for the acos total population, instead of differentiating between newly assigned and continuously assigned beneficiaries. i am concerned, however, that limiting the risk adjustment to +/- 3% over that 5 year agreement period will not protect providers who serve our most medically complicated patients. medicare beneficiaries can experience significant changes in health status over 5 years, and those changes may not be adequately addressed by the proposed methodology. our aco has been challenged by a benchmark that does not reflect the health of our population. we have worked hard to understand the mssps complex benchmarking rules and to raise awareness about the importance of coding specificity to care coordination. i am concerned that, despite our demonstrated track record of low cost and high quality, the +/- 3% cap will disadvantage our aco by continuing to incorrectly capture the health status of our beneficiaries, making shared savings unattainable.
its no secret that the abstraction of quality metrics is an onerous process, and i am encouraged by the current administrations efforts to reduce reporting burden for providers. i am also a strong advocate for transparency in scoring. should cms choose to increase the number of claims-based measures, it would be extremely helpful to provide user-friendly, actionable reports that detail the aco-specific data used to calculate specific measure performance.
i am concerned about how the enhanced notification requirements will impact my office workflow and efficiency. it will be challenging to add one more piece of paper to the stack of important documents my patients are asked to review and acknowledge at each visit. also, while i appreciate the option of providing beneficiary incentives, the administrative burden of implementation and tracking would likely create additional frustration for staff and add expense to my offices operations.
thank you for taking my comments into consideration as you work to streamline the mssp model. i look forward to seeing continued improvements in the coming years that will benefit my patients and allow me and my fellow aco participants to focus on providing high-quality and efficient care to our community.
sincerely,
jessicah s. p. collins, m.d.
diabetes and endocrinology
augusta care partners

0275:
as you know, under the current medicare shared savings program (mssp) beneficiary assignment regulations, an np is an authorized aco professional, but their patients cannot be assigned to the aco unless they receive one primary care service from a primary care physician participating with the aco each year. this has inhibited np practices from joining or establishing shared savings aco's and limited the scope of the shared savings program (mssp). if the mssp is to continue to develop and improve patient access, quality and cost effectiveness, it must be fully inclusive of nps and their patients.

therefore, i support cms' proposal to update the voluntary alignment option for beneficiary assignment in the shared savings program (mssp). this proposal would allow a patient to choose an np as their primary shared savings aco clinician and be assigned to an mssp aco without requiring a primary care service from a primary care physician. this proposal will increase the participation of nps and their patients in the mssp and is consistent with a patient-centered approach to health care delivery.

 fqhcs serve a unique role in californiaâs health care safety net. by design, fqhcs are located in medically underserved, low-income rural and urban communities and are one of the few providers who open their doors to anyone regardless of their ability to pay. on average, approximately 8% of california fqhc patients are eligible for medicare, though that number can range up to 39% and is notably higher in rural communities. most fqhc medicare patients are dually eligible for medicare and medicaid, and experience unique challenges due to their advanced age coupled with low incomes.  these challenges include high rates of chronic disease, multiple co-morbid conditions, and social and community factors that can impact their health.  because of the particularly vulnerable demographic of their patients, fqhcs contemplating risk arrangements must be especially thoughtful about risk stratification and rate setting.
 fqhc patients are not only affected by complex medical needs, but by co-occurring social needs such as food insecurity, homelessness, and lack of social support. current risk adjustment models do not adequately capture patient risk beyond traditional diagnostic criteria. this essentially penalizes providers and organizations that treat populations with greater social needs with lower risk scores (ultimately resulting in a lower financial benchmark).

re: medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizations-pathways to success [cms-1701-p]

we appreciate the opportunity to comment on the proposed modifications of the mssp aco program titled pathways to success [cms -1701-p]. careconnectmd is a physician run medical group that is planning to apply directly for the enhanced track aco in 2019. our group is comprised of primary care providers that almost exclusively care for patients living in nursing homes and assisted living facilities.
our patient base consists of the frail, elderly, and suffering from multiple complex chronic conditions. most of them suffer from cognitive impairments and are near the end of life. historically, these patients cost about three times more than the usual medicare beneficiary. it is in the context of this special needs population that we suggest modifications to the current proposal that would encourage management of this high cost group of patients more appropriately and efficiently.


claims-based determination of place of service 31 and 32

we are gratified to see that cms recognizes concerns expressed by other acos devoted to similar special needs populations. we support your proposal to utilize medicare claims of skilled nursing facility stays to validate the place of service of beneficiaries in nursing homes. using physician claims data alone is commonly inaccurate.

extension of the agreement period from three to five years

we support this proposition because it enhances predictability and stability of program.

expansion of the snf 3 day rule waiver to include snf and long-term care settings.

we approve of your proposal to expand the snf 3-day rule waiver to all qualified facilities in risk bearing acos participating in either retrospective or prospective attribution methodologies. however, most of our beneficiaries reside in a snf or long- term care setting and therefore would not qualify under the current rules. we request modifying the waiver to include these beneficiaries. our experience in medicare advantage has demonstrated the ability to directly admit to skilled nursing from nursing homes significantly reduces unnecessary hospitalizations and saves money without compromising quality. furthermore, our accountability for down side performance incentivizes us to prevent costly unnecessary nursing home snf admissions.

proposed changes to historical benchmarking and subsequent performance year adjustments

we are concerned that the proposed hcc risk adjustment to the benchmark each year may not be adequate for our population due to the rapid rate of disease progression near the end of life. our beneficiary population is almost entirely composed of patients that will expire within 3 years. we know from our experience in medicare advantage that the hcc and other medicare risk domain methodologies do not account for the additional expense of this extremely sick population, especially as the beneficiary approaches the end of life. we suggest that adding a frailty modifier to the risk adjustment (like the pace program) would better reflect the true cost of caring for this cohort.



expansion of the telehealth waiver to prospective risk acos

we support the proposed expansion of the telehealth waiver and recommend it be available to prospective and retrospective risk bearing acos. telemedicine, in our population is proving to be a powerful tool in accomplishing real time access to clinicians, including specialists in nursing and long-term care facilities. this prevents costly emergency room visits, hospitalizations, and expensive unnecessary testing.

comments on quality metrics:
pertaining to the use of opioids: we endorse the addition of opioid use quality measures. however, we are concerned that the measures be adjusted for beneficiaries that are near the end of life. for example, nqf 2940 opioids at high doses in persons without cancer or hospice does not capture appropriate situations in our patient population near the end of life in palliative care.
institutional population adjustment to utilization metrics: hospital utilization for our population is more than three times that of the average aco population. readmission and admission rates from institutionalized populations should be measured against a similar cohort population.

claims-based determination of place of service 31 and 32
we are gratified to see that cms recognizes concerns expressed by other acos devoted to similar special needs populations.  we support your proposal to utilize medicare claims of skilled nursing facility stays to validate the place of service of beneficiaries in nursing homes.  using physician claims data alone is commonly inaccurate.
extension of the agreement period from three to five years
we support cmsâs notion of enhanced predictability and stability in achievement of savings against a fixed benchmark afforded by the proposed extension of the agreement period from three to five years.
expansion of the snf 3 day rule waiver to include snf and long-term care settings.

we have the same concern about the proposal to blend regional ffs expenses into the benchmarking methodology.  we support the concept of adding a regional ffs expense modifier to protect high performing acos against an unfair lowering of their benchmark.  however, we are concerned that your regional ffs cohort representing 25% of the benchmark will not be adequately adjusted for our extremely expensive population.  if not adjusted appropriately, our benchmark could be unfairly affected to the point our special needs aco becomes unviable.  indeed, a major impetus for us to become an aco is because several of our providers have been asked to leave community based acos due to their patientâs high ffs medicare costs.
expansion of the telehealth waiver to prospective risk acos
we support the proposed expansion of the telehealth waiver and recommend it be available to prospective and retrospective risk bearing acos.  telemedicine, in our population is proving to be a powerful tool in accomplishing real time access to clinicians, including specialists in nursing and long-term care facilities.  this prevents costly emergency room visits, hospitalizations, and expensive unnecessary testing.

institutional population adjustment to utilization metrics:  hospital utilization for our population is more than three times that of the average aco population.  readmission and admission rates from institutionalized populations should be measured against a similar cohort population.

dear administrator verma,

augusta care partners is an accountable care organization (aco) based in rural virginia that represents
a strong partnership between independent physician practices and a community hospital with employed
providers. we are currently in our second agreement period as a track 1 aco in the medicare shared
savings program (mssp).

it is important to note that while our aco has not yet achieved shared savings, we have maintained
quality scores in the top quartile of all mssp acos and, at the same time, have sustained one of the
lowest cost-per-beneficiary rates across all mssp acos. these results can be directly tied to significant
investments in improving coordination of care and our team of providers being committed to generating
positive outcomes for medicare beneficiaries in our community. as a participating augusta care
partners provider, i feel it is important to voice my opinion on a few key points in the mssp proposed
rule, medicare program; medicare shared savings program; accountable care organizations pathways
to success.

providing an opportunity to choose prospective attribution in both the basic and enhanced
tracks is a significant improvement. our aco has been challenged by the uncertainty of
preliminary prospective beneficiary assignment with retrospective reconciliation. having the
option to definitively know our attributed patient panel at the beginning of the year offers some
much-needed stability and helps guide the appropriate allocation of our acos finite resources.

the flexibility offered by the snf waiver is a huge benefit. i appreciate that cms is expanding
access to this important program feature.

i am hopeful that the 5 year agreement periods offered in both the basic and enhanced tracks
will create increased predictability in the program. it is also a welcome change to have risk
scores updated annually for the acos total population, instead of differentiating between
newly assigned and continuously assigned beneficiaries. i am concerned, however, that
limiting the risk adjustment to +/- 3% over that 5 year agreement period will not protect
providers who serve our most medically complicated patients. medicare beneficiaries can
experience significant changes in health status over 5 years, and those changes may not be
adequately addressed by the proposed methodology. our aco has been challenged by a
benchmark that does not reflect the health of our population. we have worked hard to
understand the mssps complex benchmarking rules and to raise awareness about the
importance of coding specificity to care coordination. i am concerned that, despite our
demonstrated track record of low cost and high quality, the +/- 3% cap will disadvantage our
aco by continuing to incorrectly capture the health status of our beneficiaries, making shared
savings unattainable.

its no secret that the abstraction of quality metrics is an onerous process, and i am encouraged
by the current administrations efforts to reduce reporting burden for providers. i am also a
strong advocate for transparency in scoring. should cms choose to increase the number of
claims-based measures, it would be extremely helpful to provide user-friendly, actionable
reports that detail the aco-specific data used to calculate specific measure performance.

i am concerned about how the enhanced notification requirements will impact my office
workflow and efficiency. it will be challenging to add one more piece of paper to the stack of
important documents my patients are asked to review and acknowledge at each visit. also,
while i appreciate the option of providing beneficiary incentives, the administrative burden of
implementation and tracking would likely create additional frustration for staff and add expense
to my offices operations.

thank you for taking my comments into consideration as you work to streamline the mssp model. i look
forward to seeing continued improvements in the coming years that will benefit my patients and allow
me and my fellow aco participants to focus on providing high-quality and efficient care to our
community.

sincerely,

jay sailer, md
maury river family practice, llc
augusta care partners

 nosorh  comments on cms revisions for the medicare shared savings program â accountable care organizations
 overview on august 17, 2018 the centers for medicare and medicaid  services (cms) published proposed rules entitled medicare shared savings program (mssp) - accountable care organizations (acos) - pathways to success (cmsâ1701âp). in this communication, the national  organization  of state offices of rural health (nosorh) makes comment and recommendation  related to these proposed rules. nosorhâs comments are specific to the sections of the proposed rules which would reduce the permitted term of aco participation  in the track 1 â upside only category. the comments also pertain to the proposed changes to medicare payments for acos in an upside-only category. the comments will explore how the proposed rules will  affect rural aco participation  in the aco. the comments are followed  by specific recommendations about how cms might modify its proposals to assure continued  participation  of rural health care providers in the mssp.
 general comments nosorh has assessed the current status of rural health care providers in mssp acos. based upon  this assessment nosorh has identified  the likely implications  of the proposed changes on rural acos. this analysis is summarized in the following  comments.
 rural acos - description a substantial number of accountable care organizations currently in operation include rural health care providers. an august 2018 report from the rural policy research institute (rupri) indicates  that in 2017 53 acos include a provider group that is either exclusively or largely located in non-metro locations. this represents 10.2% of the 520 total acos in the enumeration.  an additional  144 acos include  a mixed metro/nonmetro provider group. this means that an additional 27.7% of the total number of acos are having some rural impact. a january 2018 cms estimate, cited by caravan health, indicated  that 66 of 561 mssp acos (11.8%) had participation  by some rural providers. this estimate is consistent with the 2017 rupri enumeration for acos with health providers either exclusively or largely located in non-metro areas.
 almost all the rural acos are currently in track 1. the rupri report indicates that almost all acos that include rural providers are in the track 1 - upside only category. 50 of the 53 acos (94%) with health providers largely or exclusively from rural locations  are in track 1. 124 of the 144 acos (86.1%) with mixed rural/urban health providers are in track 1. both percentages are higher than the 84.8%  of all acos in track 1.

 such as training  and modifications  to data systems. while this average figure covers a range of different individual  aco levels of expenditure, the same survey showed that 87% of all aco respondents replied that their investments in aco startup and operation were either significant  or very significant.
 these additional costs are an important factor affecting the potential  return on investment of participating  in the mssp. if shared savings cannot offset these additional  costs, an aco will be facing a net loss. despite this reality, cms does not fully consider  the additional  costs associated with aco operation in its calculations for the program.
 rural acos face greater cost challenges than do many urban acos. rural acos generally have lower patient volumes than do urban acos. as a result, the implementation  cost per patient in rural acos is higher. it may be prohibitive. many rural acos need support to be able to cover these costs.
 the importance of upfront costs for rural acos is indicated by the significant number of rural acos supported under the aco investment model (aim) initiative - a one-time program which supports infrastructure development for rural or underserved area acos established in or before performance year 2016. according to a rupri study, in 2017 75% of acos with health providers exclusively in rural locations were aim participants. 35.6% of acos with health providers largely in rural locations were aim participants. 11.1% of acos with mixed rural/urban health providers were aim participants. these numbers point to the disparate challenges faced by rural acos in managing  the costs of running  an effective aco.
 it should be noted that aco costs are not limited to aco patients. acos will generally implement system-wide infrastructure changes for all patients, not just aco enrolled patients. for example, data processing  improvements will  often be system-wide for participating providers. in this way, aco benefits will not be limited to aco enrolled  patients. the changes in infrastructure and systems will likely lead to improvements for all patients of participating  providers. these benefits, including  quality and cost improvements, are not part of the measurement and assessment of the mssp.
 rural acos â resulting savings âsavingsâ, as calculated  for acos are the difference between actual patient cost and the historically  benchmarked patient cost for aco enrolled patients. with smaller enrolled patient populations such as those in rural acos, the historical  costs of an enrolled population  may be volatile. if a relatively small number of patients develop serious new health problems, the service costs for the enrolled population  could quickly surpass the benchmark. this will likely put smaller rural acos at greater risk than larger, urban acos for failing  to reduce estimated costs.
 despite this challenge,  several studies indicate  that rural acos can achieve substantial medicare savings for their enrolled patient population.  these savings are achieved by acos that are largely track 1, upside only organizations:

 in a key study, a cms evaluation of the aim program showed that in their first performance year aim acos showed lowered medicare spending  with no sign of decrements in quality of care. the study showed that acos with upside-only financial  risk in rural areas can, with up-front funding  and management company support, achieve mssp aims.  in 2016, 41 aim acos demonstrated $105.4 million in reduced total medicare spending  relative to similar  traditional  medicare beneficiaries  in the same geographic area. 30 of the 41 acos had lower total medicare spending  than the baseline for their enrolled  patients. the aim acos showed $82.8  million  in net savings to the medicare program after subtracting earned shared savings.
 a follow-up study of aim acos showed similar  savings performance for 2017. in that year 45 aim acos â including  several new first year acos â demonstrated a total of $81 million in lower medicare spending.  the aim acos had a lower per capita spending of $172 per year, a figure which surpassed the $138 per year savings of track 3 acos in the mssp for the same period. this indicates  that the downside risk assumption is not a predictive factor in the savings performance of acos, and that the performance of rural acos in track 1 is significant  even without downside risk assumption.
 several other studies point to key factors for rural aco success. some studies point to year-to-year improvement in aco performance, demonstrating an operational learning  curve. other studies show differences between physician-only aco organizations  and hospital-inclusive acos. a few studies have suggested that acos supported by professional  management companies  fare better than do others which do not. what seems clear is that understanding of aco savings performance is just beginning  to emerge. it may be premature to make major mssp changes, particularly if rural aco participation  in the program is to be maintained.
 as mentioned previously, the medicare savings gained from aco operation is not limited to aco enrolled  patients. as discussed in the mssp pathways to success proposed rule, cms estimates that the overall impact of acos, including  âspillover effectsâ on medicare spending  outside of the aco program, lowered spending by
$1.8 â $4.2 billion  (0.5 â 1.2 percent) in 2016 alone. these analyses provide 
 important evidence that acos save more money for medicare than what is reflected in the basic evaluations of performance.
 it should be noted that those acos which  fail to achieve savings over their enrolled patientsâ benchmarks do not actually âloseâ money. these acos only fail to achieve targeted savings. services to aco enrolled  patients are paid on the same fee for service payment schedule that is used for non-enrolled  patients. should  acos leave the mssp these patients would continue  to cost medicare the same. the exit of acos from the program would simply eliminate incentives for reducing cost and improving quality in the future.




 readiness of rural acos for risk assumption a survey conducted by naaco of all mssp acos indicated  that most of the acos in track 1 would likely leave the mssp if they were to prematurely lose the 5% apm incentive for participation. this survey showed that only 33% of respondents in track 1 would be somewhat likely or very likely to continue their participation. the potential drop in track 1 aco participation  in the mssp would be even greater if these acos were further forced to assume downside risk. a 2018 naaco survey indicated  that 71% of all track 1 acos would likely leave the mssp if forced to assume downside risk. given that 86% of rural acos are in track 1, elimination  of upside-only risk arrangements would likely lead to an exodus of most rural acos from the program.
 being accountable  for health care does not necessarily require the inappropriate assumption  of risk. while  rural acos, as a cohort, have demonstrated the ability to generate medicare spending reductions,  in any given year some rural acos may not be able to achieve savings. if they were to be forced into inappropriate  assumption of losses, they might face financial  challenges in those years. inappropriate assumption  of risk by fragile rural provider organizations  could  threaten rural health system sustainability and runs counter to the purpose of the aca â improving access to affordable, quality health care.
 summary nosorh believes that the aim of the mssp in rural areas should  be to permit widespread participation of rural health care providers in accountable care payment mechanisms. this does not necessarily involve the assumption of inappropriate risk. while  some rural acos are ready to assume a level of downside  risk, a larger number may not be immediately able to make this transition.  in addition,  required assumption  of inappropriate risk may create disincentives for other rural health care providers from joining  into new aco arrangements.
 nosorh believes that incentive mechanisms  should be maintained  to permit rural acos to generate medicare savings on a discontinuous basis â allowing  shared savings in some years while not putting rural health services at risk in years when no savings are forthcoming. this would  require continuation  and enhancement of the track 1 type payment arrangements. nosorh  believes that these arrangements are a net benefit to medicare. they would permit patient payment savings in some years and would cost no more than patient payments on the current fee for service schedule in others.  in line with this perspective nosorh makes the following  recommendations  to cms.
 recommendations in line with the analysis discussed previously, nosorh  makes the following recommendations  to cms. recommendation 1 - maintain current track 1 incentive structure: nosorh believes that the current multi-year participation  arrangements give rural acos realistic term for implementation  of accountable care systems. nosorh recommends that cms maintain the existing track 1 structure and incentives for both continuing and new rural acos.

 recommendation 2 - maintain eligibility of track 1 acos for apm incentives: nosorh believes that participation  in a track 1 aco shows a commitment of a health care organization  to accountable  care. track 1 acos have been shown to generate savings for medicare with no loss of quality. nosorh recommends that cms maintain the eligibility of track 1 acos for alternative payment model (apm) incentives and mips exclusions.
 recommendation 3 - permanent extension of track 1 aco arrangements: nosorh believes that assumption  of downside risk is not essential for successful accountable care. nosorh  feels that rural acos can contribute to accountable  care and to medicare savings on a continuing  basis while operating as track 1 acos. nosorh recommends that cms consider allowing acos to operate with track 1 â upside only - arrangements on a permanent basis.
 recommendation 4 - additional support for costs of aco participation: nosorh recognizes that all acos face substantial implementation  and operational costs. these costs can make aco participation  prohibitive for many rural acos, particularly those in underserved areas.  nosorh recommends that cms use the lessons of the aim program to develop new support mechanisms for acos in rural and underserved areas.

providing an opportunity to choose prospective attribution in both the basic and enhanced tracks is a significant improvement. our aco has been challenged by the uncertainty of preliminary prospective beneficiary assignment with retrospective reconciliation. having the option to definitively know our attributed patient panel at the beginning of the year offers some much-needed stability and helps guide the appropriate allocation of our acoâs finite resources.
the flexibility offered by the snf waiver is a huge benefit. i appreciate that cms is expanding access to this important program feature.

as you know, under the current medicare shared savings program (mssp) beneficiary assignment regulations, an np is an authorized aco professional, but their patients cannot be assigned to the aco unless they receive one primary care service from a primary care physician participating with the aco each year. this has inhibited np practices from joining or establishing shared savings aco's and limited the scope of the shared savings program (mssp). if the mssp is to continue to develop and improve patient access, quality and cost effectiveness, it must be fully inclusive of nps and their patients.
